title-group.article-title: Phytochemical and nutrient/antinutrient interactions in cherry tomato (Lycopersicon esculentum) fruits

article-meta.aff: Department of Biochemistry, Ekiti-State University, Nigeria

author-notes.corresp: Folake Lucy Oyetayo, Department of Biochemistry, Ekiti-State University, Ado-Ekiti, P.M.B 5363 Ekiti-State, Nigeria. Email: ovounad@yahoo.com

abstract.p: The fruit of the cherry tomato (Lycopersicon esculentum (Solanaceae)) was analysed for mineral and antinutrient composition. Phosphorus (33.04 ± 0.21 mg/100g) was the most abundant mineral in the fruit, followed by calcium (32.04 ± 0.06 mg/100g), and potassium (11.9 ± 0.1 mg/100g) and manganese (9.55 ± 0.28 mg/100g) were also present in appreciable quantities. Antinutrients, including phytate, glycoside, saponin and tannin, were screened and quantified. Phytate (112.82 ± 0.1 mg/100g), glycoside (2.33 ± 0.00 mg/100g), saponin (1.31 ± 0.00 mg/100g) and tannin (0.21 ± 0.00 mg/100g) were present in the fruit but phlobatanin and glycosides with steroidal rings were not found. The calculated calcium:phytate ratio of the fruits was below the critical value and the calculated [calcium] [phytate]:[zinc] molar ratio was less than the critical value. The calcium:phosphorus ratio (0.97 mg/100g) shows the fruit to be a good source of food nutrients, while the sodium:potassium value was less than 1. Ca/P ratio below 0.5 indicates deficiency of these minerals while Na/K ratio above 1 is detrimental because of excessive sodium levels. The results of the study generally revealed the fruit to be rich in minerals but containing insufficient quantities of antinutrients to result in poor mineral bioavailability.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Fruits form an important part of human diets and are usually regarded as good food (Brain and Alan, 1992). Their consumption has been associated with a decreased risk of breast cancer (Zhang et al., 2009).

The cherry tomato plant (Lycopersicon esculentum) is a member of the nightshade family (Solanaceae) of the genus Solanum, the fruit of which is edible and ripens to distinctive red or yellow colours. The fruit has fleshy internal segments filled with slippery seeds surrounded by a watery matrix. The seed contains about 24% semidrying oil, which is useful as salad oil; the residual mass is employed as a stocked feed and fertilizer (Hill, 1999). It originated from South America, and spread around the world following the Spanish colonization of the Americas (Smith, 1994).

The consumption of tomato fruit is believed to benefit the heart, among other organs. The fruit contains lycopene, one of the most powerful natural antioxidants (Sesso et al., 2003). Studies have shown that lycopene, especially from cooked tomatoes, helps prevent prostate cancer (Jian et al., 2007), improves the skin’s ability to protect against harmful ultraviolet rays and slows eventual senility; hence, it is used as a non-chemical cosmetic by young girls (Stahl and Sies, 2004).

Cherry tomato fruits contain phytochemicals that possess antioxidant, antibacterial, antifungal, antiviral and anticarcinogenic properties (Steinmetz and Potter, 1996). The fruit is used in diverse ways, including raw in salads and processed into ketchup or tomato soup. It is acidic, making it easy to preserve in a home canning process, chopped as tomato sauce or as a paste. The tomato fruit is an important ingredient in soup preparations and is consumed in the ripe form as a source of minerals and vitamins (Sowunmi et al., 1986). In Nigeria, the cherry tomato plant is not usually cultivated; rather, it grows in the wild and, given this, its consumption is not popular. Hence, there is a paucity of information on its chemical composition.
The present study hopes to provide information on the mineral and antinutrient compositions of the cherry tomato fruit and to encourage its husbandry if worthwhile.

sec.title: Materials and methods
sec.p: Cherry tomato fruits were obtained from a farm located on the Ado–Ekiti road in Ikere-Ekiti, Nigeria, and subsequently oven dried at 60°C and powdered. The minerals were analysed from the solution obtained by, first, dry ashing; 1g of the sample was placed in a crucible in a muffle furnace at 550°C for 5 hours to ash and then transferred into a desiccator to cool. The cooled ash was dissolved in 10% hydrochloric acid and filtered into clean graduated sample bottles. The solution was made to 50 mL with deionized water and analysed for potassium, sodium, calcium, magnesium, zinc, iron and manganese using the atomic absorption spectrometer and for phosphorus using ultraviolet-visible spectrophotometer at 436 nm after making an ammonium molybdate–vanadate complex according to the established procedure of Perkin–Elmer (1982).

The powdered sample was screened for the presence of phytochemicals such as saponin, tannin, phlobatanins, anthraquinones and cardiac glycosides as described by standard methods (Harborne, 1973; Sofowora, 1993; Trease, 1989). Tannin content was determined as follows: 200 mg of three replicates of the sample were extracted with 70% acetone. Standard tannic acid solution (50 mg/100 mL) was prepared and serial dilutions were made. Absorbances of the solutions were measured at 725 nm after the addition of 0.5 mL folin and 2.5 mL 20% NaCO3 (Marker et al., 1993). To determine the cyanide concentration, 4g of the sample were soaked in a mixture of 2 mL orthophosphoric acid and 40 mL distilled water overnight to free-bound cyanide. The resulting solution was distilled and the distillate was titrated against 0.01 M AgNO3. Flavonoid concentration was obtained as follows: 100 mL of 80% aqueous methanol was used to extract 10g of sample repeatedly at room temperature and filtered through Whatman filter paper (no. 42, 125 mm). The filtrate was evaporated to dryness in a crucible over a water bath until a constant weight was reached (Bohnm and Kocipal-Abyazan, 1994).

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: Table 1 presents the mineral composition of Lycopersicon esculentum (Solanaceae) fruit. The most abundant mineral in the fruit was phosphorus (33.04 ± 0.21 mg/100g), followed by calcium (32.04 ± 0.06 mg/100g). These concentrations were higher than the 2.7 mg/100g obtained by Burton and Foster (1988) for Lycopersicon esculentum (Cerasiforme) but lower than the 76 mg/100g reported by Adenipekun and Oyetunji (2010) for Lycopersicon esculentum (Cerasiforme). Calcium is an important constituent of bones and teeth. Hence, the consumption of the fruit could be important for the prevention of osteoporesis, rickets and colon cancer. The fruits contain phosphorus, calcium and magnesium in appreciable amounts. These minerals are important for bone formation and their deficiencies can lead to abnormal bone development (Aletor and Aladetimi, 1989). Iron composition (0.4 mg/100g) of the cherry fruit is comparable to the 0.6 mg/100g obtained by Ihekoronye and Ngoddy (1985). Iron is required for blood formation and it is also important in normal functioning of the central nervous system (Shills et al., 1992). Manganese, a nutritionally valuable mineral element, was also present in the fruit in appreciable quantity. Manganese is required by several metalo-enzymatic reactions such as those catalysed by superoxide dismutase, an antioxidant enzyme that is protective against unstable cell-damaging free radicals and also required for proper bone and cartilage formation.

caption.p: Mineral composition (mg/100g) of Lycopersicon esculentum (Solanaceae) fruit.

sec.p: Table 2 presents the calculated mineral–mineral and phytochemical interaction ratios. The ratio of sodium to potassium in the body is important for the prevention of high blood pressure. The sodium:potassium ratio of the fruit of Lycopersicon esculentum was less than 1.0. Hence, consumption of the fruit could help prevent the incidence of high blood pressure. Food is considered ‘good’ if the calcium:phospohorus ratio is above 1.0 and ‘poor’ if the ratio is less than 0.5, and a calcium:phosphorus ratio above 2.0 helps to increase the absorption of calcium in the small intestine (Agatemor, 2007). The calcium:phosphorus ratio of the fruit (0.97) showed that it is not a poor source of calcium and zinc since the ratio was above 0.5. The calcium:magnesium ratio of 3.35 was higher than the recommended value of 1.0 (Shills et al., 1992). The importance of food dietary micronutrients depends on the total mineral content and on the level of other constituents in the diet that affect their bioavailability. Antinutrients affect or inhibit the availability of certain nutrients despite their adequate consumption. They can lead to trace element deficiency because some form stable complexes with minerals, which renders them unavailable for intestinal uptake. The calcium:phytate ratio of Lycopersicon esculentum fruit was 5:1, which is less than the 6:1 critical value. However, the [calcium][phytate]/[zinc] molar ratio is a better predictor of bioavailability of calcium and zinc than either the [calcium]:[phytate] or [zinc]:[phytate] molar ratio. The [calcium]/[phytate]/[zinc] molar ratio of the Lycopersicon esculentum fruit was 0.03. This is less than the critical value of 0.5.

caption.p: Calculated mineral:mineral ratio for phytate:zinc and calcium:phytate, and [calcium]:[phytate]:[zinc] molar ratio of cherry tomato.

sec.p: Phytochemical screening of the Lycopersicon esculentum (Solanaceae) fruit as shown in Table 3 revealed that saponin, anthraquinone and glycosides were present in the fruit whereas phlobatanin and steroidal glycosides were absent. Cardiac glycosides are known to be useful in the treatment of congestive heart failure (Schneider and Wolfling, 2004). They have been scientifically proven to have some anti-inflammatory effects on conjunctivitis (Fish and Fish, 1996).

caption.p: Phytochemical composition of Lycopersicon esculentum fruit.

sec.p: The antinutrient composition of Lycopersicon esculentum (Solanaceae) fruit is shown in Table 4. The phytate concentration (mg/100g) of the fruit was 112.82 ± 0.0 mg/100g. Depending on its concentration, phytate can influence the functional and nutritional properties of food. Also, it has the ability to potentially lower blood glucose, reduce cholesterol and triacylglycerols and reduce the risk of cancer through its absorption of divalent and multivalent minerals, which cancerous cells require for growth. The tannin concentration of Lycopersicon esculentum (Solanaceae) fruit was 0.20 ± 0.00%. Tannin helps to control indications of gastritis, esophagitis, enteritis and irritable bowel disorders. It is also effective in protecting the kidneys, giving immediate relief of sore throat, diarrhoea, dysentry, hemorrhaging, fatigue and skin ulcers (Shimomura et al., 2004). Apart from its health benefits, tannin serves as a defensive chemical, protecting plants from predatory attacks of herbivores, pathogenic fungi and parasitic weeds. In Humans, it is defensive at certain concentrations against reactive oxygen species due to its content of some naturally occurring phytochemicals. Cyanide concentration of the Lycopersicon esculentum (Solanaceae) fruit is 0.5 mg/100g, which is higher than the 0.09 mg/100g reported for the guinea corn (Sorghum vulgare) grain (FAO, 1988). Cyanide is a normal body constituent (Osagie, 1998) but it is a potent respiratory chain inhibitor at high concentrations (Leningher, 1987). Saponin (1.31 mg/100g) concentration was lower than the 1.99 mg/100g obtained by Ogundana and Kayode (1982), for the edible mushroom Pleurotus tuber-regium Saponin possesses antioxidant properties (Birk and Peri, 1980), and its toxicity is related to its ability to lower surface tension (Schipper, 2002).

In conclusion, the result of the present study revealed that cherry tomato fruits are rich in minerals and have an insufficient antinutrient content to result in poor mineral bioavailability; therefore, its cultivation and consumption is encouraged to provide an additional source of minerals, especially in developing countries.
